title: Why didn't Finland get Karelia back after the fall of the Soviet union? - Quora

response.answer_text: One could similarly ask why Poland didn't get back its eastern territories and cede its western ones and east Prussia to Germany. Or why the Kaliningrad Oblast would not be included in the package… and why Lithuania didn’t have to cede Vilnius/Wilno to Poland. Karelia, for its part was Annexed to RUSSIA during the war, while Estonia , Latvia and Lithuania were annexed as constituent republics into the USSR. in 1991 the USSR ceased to legally exist, while Russia continued its legal existence. Had Karelia been annexed as a constituent Soviet Socialist Republic of the USSR, its independence would have likely come, followed by reunion with Finland.

Because it did not ask it back or want it back. Had Finland initiated talks on Karelia’s future status with Yeltsin’s Russia, “questions” would have ensued: the Silesian “question”, the “question” of East Prussia, you name it. Honestly, does somebody think Finland, of all countries, could have done something as rash and destabilizing as this?
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Qtizananto Zacharias Frans Hendrik
